science.text: Which type of rock forms in layers, is often found near water, and contains fossils?
science.explanation: Sedimentary rocks form in layers (strata) as sediment is deposited, often in bodies of water, and may contain fossils of plants and animals that were buried in the sediment.

science.text: What is the most abundant chemical element in the universe?
science.explanation: Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, making up about 75% of the baryonic mass.

science.text: Which planet is known as the 'red planet'?
science.explanation: Mars is known as the 'red planet' due to its characteristic reddish color caused by iron oxide on its surface.

science.text: What is the largest organ in the human body?
science.explanation: Skin is the largest organ in the human body, with an average surface area of about 2 square meters and a weight that represents about 16% of body weight.

science.text: Which gas is responsible for the hole in the ozone layer?
science.explanation: Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are the main cause of the ozone hole, as they release chlorine that destroys ozone molecules.

science.text: What is the speed of light in vacuum?
science.explanation: The speed of light in vacuum is exactly 299,792,458 meters per second, often rounded to 300,000 km/s.

science.text: Which scientist formulated the theory of relativity?
science.explanation: Albert Einstein formulated the theory of relativity, publishing the theory of special relativity in 1905 and general relativity in 1915.

science.text: What is the chemical symbol for gold?
science.explanation: The chemical symbol for gold is Au, derived from the Latin word 'aurum'.

science.text: Which disease is caused by vitamin C deficiency?
science.explanation: Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency and causes symptoms such as fatigue, bleeding gums, and joint pain.

science.text: What is the name of the cell division process that produces gametes?
science.explanation: Meiosis is the cell division process that produces gametes (sex cells) with half the number of chromosomes compared to somatic cells.

science.text: What is the name of the theoretical particle that gives mass to other particles?
science.explanation: The Higgs Boson, discovered in 2012 at CERN, is the particle associated with the Higgs field that gives mass to other fundamental particles.

science.text: Which quantum number describes the spin of an electron?
science.explanation: The spin quantum number describes the intrinsic angular momentum of an electron and can have values of +1/2 or -1/2.

science.text: What is the name of the process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy?
science.explanation: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy, producing glucose and oxygen from carbon dioxide and water.

science.text: Which type of RNA carries amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis?
science.explanation: Transfer RNA (tRNA) carries amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis, matching them to the appropriate codons on the mRNA.

science.text: What is the name of the force that holds quarks together?
science.explanation: The Strong Nuclear Force is the fundamental force that holds quarks together to form protons and neutrons.

science.text: Which enzyme is responsible for unwinding DNA during replication?
science.explanation: Helicase is the enzyme responsible for unwinding the double-stranded DNA molecule during DNA replication.

science.text: What is the name of the process by which a star converts hydrogen into helium?
science.explanation: Nuclear fusion is the process by which stars convert hydrogen into helium, releasing enormous amounts of energy.

science.text: Which type of bond is formed by the sharing of electron pairs between atoms?
science.explanation: A covalent bond is formed when atoms share electron pairs, creating a strong chemical bond between the atoms.

science.text: What is the name of the process by which cells break down glucose to produce energy?
science.explanation: Cellular respiration is the process by which cells break down glucose to produce ATP, the cell's energy currency.

science.text: Which type of radiation has the highest energy?
science.explanation: Gamma radiation has the highest energy of all types of radiation, with the ability to penetrate through most materials.

entertainment.text: Which actor played Iron Man in the Marvel Cinematic Universe?
entertainment.explanation: Robert Downey Jr. played Tony Stark / Iron Man in the Marvel Cinematic Universe from 2008 to 2019.

entertainment.text: Who directed the film 'La vita è bella'?
entertainment.explanation: Roberto Benigni directed and starred in the film 'La vita è bella' in 1997, winning three Academy Awards.

entertainment.text: Which film won the Oscar for Best Picture in 2020?
answers: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood
entertainment.explanation: Parasite won the Oscar for Best Picture in 2020, becoming the first non-English language film to receive this recognition.

entertainment.text: Who played the role of Jack Dawson in Titanic?
entertainment.explanation: Leonardo DiCaprio played the role of Jack Dawson in the 1997 film Titanic.

entertainment.text: Which TV series has won the most Emmy Awards?
entertainment.explanation: Game of Thrones has won 59 Emmy Awards, more than any other TV series in history.
Francis Ford Coppola directed the film 'The Godfather' in 1972, based on the novel by Mario Puzo.

entertainment.text: Which singer is nicknamed 'The Queen of Pop'?
entertainment.explanation: Madonna is nicknamed 'The Queen of Pop' for her impact on popular music and her longevity in the music industry.

entertainment.text: Which film has won the most Oscars in history?
answers: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
entertainment.explanation: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King won 11 Oscars in 2004, tying the record with Ben-Hur and Titanic.

entertainment.text: Who played the role of Harry Potter in the films?
entertainment.explanation: Daniel Radcliffe played the role of Harry Potter in all eight films of the series.

entertainment.text: Which musical group released the album 'Abbey Road'?
entertainment.explanation: The Beatles released the album 'Abbey Road' in 1969, their eleventh studio album.

entertainment.text: Which film won the first Academy Award for Best Picture?
entertainment.explanation: Wings won the first Academy Award for Best Picture in 1929, at the first Academy Awards ceremony.

entertainment.text: Who composed the soundtrack for 'The Godfather'?
entertainment.explanation: Nino Rota composed the iconic soundtrack for 'The Godfather', including the famous main theme.

entertainment.text: Which Broadway musical holds the record for the longest-running show?
entertainment.explanation: The Phantom of the Opera holds the record for the longest-running Broadway show, with over 13,000 performances.

entertainment.text: Who directed the first Star Wars film?
entertainment.explanation: George Lucas directed the first Star Wars film, 'Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope', released in 1977.

entertainment.text: Which actor has won the most Academy Awards for Best Actor?
entertainment.explanation: Daniel Day-Lewis has won three Academy Awards for Best Actor, more than any other actor in history.

entertainment.text: Which film was the first to be rated PG-13?
answers: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom
entertainment.explanation: Gremlins was one of the first films to be rated PG-13, leading to the creation of the rating in 1984.

entertainment.text: Which film won the first animated feature Academy Award?
entertainment.explanation: Beauty and the Beast was the first animated film to be nominated for Best Picture and won the first Academy Award for Best Animated Feature in 2002.

entertainment.text: Who composed the music for 'The Lord of the Rings' trilogy?
entertainment.explanation: Howard Shore composed the music for 'The Lord of the Rings' trilogy, winning three Academy Awards for his work.

entertainment.text: Which film was the first to use CGI?
entertainment.explanation: Tron (1982) was one of the first films to extensively use computer-generated imagery (CGI) in its production.

sports.text: In which city were the 2020 Olympics held (which took place in 2021)?
sports.explanation: The 2020 Olympics were held in Tokyo, Japan, but were postponed to 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

sports.text: Which team has won the most Champions League titles?
sports.explanation: Real Madrid has won 14 Champions League titles, more than any other team in the history of the competition.

sports.text: In which year did Italy win its fourth World Cup title?
sports.explanation: Italy won its fourth World Cup title in 2006, defeating France on penalties in the final.

sports.text: Which tennis player has won the most Grand Slam titles in men's singles?
sports.explanation: Novak Djokovic has won 24 Grand Slam titles in men's singles, more than any other tennis player in history.

sports.text: Which country has won the most gold medals at the Summer Olympics?
sports.explanation: The United States has won the most gold medals at the Summer Olympics, with over 1,000 gold medals.

sports.text: Which driver has won the most Formula 1 world championships?
sports.explanation: Lewis Hamilton has won 7 Formula 1 world championships, tying Michael Schumacher's record.

sports.text: Which NBA team has won the most championships?
sports.explanation: The Boston Celtics have won 17 NBA championships, more than any other team in the history of the league.
Muhammad Ali is nicknamed 'The Greatest' and is considered one of the greatest boxers of all time.

sports.text: Which country has won the most World Cup titles in football?
sports.explanation: Brazil has won 5 World Cup titles in football, more than any other country in the history of the competition.

sports.text: Which country has won the most Olympic gold medals in swimming?
sports.explanation: The United States has won the most Olympic gold medals in swimming, with over 250 gold medals.

sports.text: Who holds the record for the most goals scored in a single World Cup tournament?
sports.explanation: Just Fontaine scored 13 goals in the 1958 World Cup, a record that still stands today.

sports.text: Which tennis player has won the most Grand Slam titles in women's singles?
sports.explanation: Margaret Court has won 24 Grand Slam titles in women's singles, more than any other player.

sports.text: Which country has won the most Rugby World Cup titles?
sports.explanation: New Zealand has won the most Rugby World Cup titles, with three victories.

sports.text: Who holds the record for the most points scored in an NBA game?
sports.explanation: Wilt Chamberlain scored 100 points in a single NBA game in 1962, a record that still stands.

sports.text: Which country has won the most Olympic gold medals in athletics?
sports.explanation: The United States has won the most Olympic gold medals in athletics, with over 300 gold medals.

sports.text: Who holds the record for the most goals scored in a single NHL season?
sports.explanation: Wayne Gretzky scored 92 goals in the 1981-82 NHL season, a record that still stands.

sports.text: Which country has won the most Olympic gold medals in boxing?
sports.explanation: Cuba has won the most Olympic gold medals in boxing, with over 70 gold medals.

art.explanation: The Mona Lisa was painted by Leonardo da Vinci between 1503 and 1519.

art.text: Who sculpted the David statue housed in the Accademia Gallery in Florence?
art.explanation: The David is a sculpture created by Michelangelo Buonarroti between 1501 and 1504.

art.text: Which artist painted the Sistine Chapel?
art.explanation: Michelangelo painted the Sistine Chapel between 1508 and 1512, creating one of the most famous masterpieces in art history.
Vincent van Gogh painted 'The Starry Night' in 1889, during his stay at the psychiatric hospital in Saint-Rémy.

art.text: Which artistic movement is associated with Salvador Dalí?
art.explanation: Salvador Dalí is one of the main exponents of Surrealism, an artistic movement that explores the unconscious and dreams.
Leonardo da Vinci painted 'L'ultima cena' between 1495 and 1498 in the refectory of the convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Milan.

art.text: Which artist created the sculpture 'The Thinker'?
art.explanation: Auguste Rodin created the sculpture 'The Thinker' between 1880 and 1902, originally conceived as part of 'The Gates of Hell'.
Pablo Picasso painted 'Guernica' in 1937 as a response to the bombing of the Basque town of Guernica during the Spanish Civil War.

art.text: Which artist created the Trevi Fountain in Rome?
art.explanation: Nicola Salvi designed the Trevi Fountain, completed in 1762, although the original design dates back to Bernini.

art.text: Who painted 'The Persistence of Memory' with the melting clocks?
art.explanation: Salvador Dalí painted 'The Persistence of Memory' in 1931, one of his most famous paintings featuring melting clocks.
Sandro Botticelli painted 'The Birth of Venus' in the 1480s, one of the most famous works of the Italian Renaissance.
Edvard Munch painted 'The Scream' in 1893, one of the most famous works of Expressionism.

art.text: Which artist created the 'Campidoglio' in Rome?
art.explanation: Michelangelo designed the 'Campidoglio' (Capitoline Hill) in Rome, including its famous piazza and buildings.
Rembrandt painted 'The Night Watch' in 1642, one of the most famous works of the Dutch Golden Age.

art.text: Which artist created the 'Gates of Paradise' in Florence?
art.explanation: Lorenzo Ghiberti created the 'Gates of Paradise', the bronze doors of the Florence Baptistery, between 1425 and 1452.

art.text: Who painted 'The Garden of Earthly Delights'?
art.explanation: Hieronymus Bosch painted 'The Garden of Earthly Delights' between 1490 and 1510, a triptych known for its complex symbolism.

art.text: Which artist created the 'Ecstasy of Saint Teresa'?
art.explanation: Gian Lorenzo Bernini created the 'Ecstasy of Saint Teresa' between 1647 and 1652, a masterpiece of Baroque sculpture.
Jan van Eyck painted 'The Arnolfini Portrait' in 1434, one of the most famous works of the Northern Renaissance.

geography.text: Which country is shown in this image?
geography.explanation: The image shows Lithuania, recognizable by its position between Latvia and Belarus in the Baltic countries.

geography.text: Which is the largest ocean on Earth?
geography.explanation: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth, covering more than 30% of the Earth's surface.

geography.text: What is the capital of Australia?
geography.explanation: Canberra is the capital of Australia, not Sydney or Melbourne as many erroneously believe.

geography.text: Which is the longest river in the world?
geography.explanation: The Nile is the longest river in the world, with a length of about 6,650 km, although the Amazon River has a greater volume of water.

geography.text: Which country has the largest population in the world?
geography.explanation: India surpassed China as the most populous country in the world in 2023, with a population of over 1.4 billion people.

geography.text: Which desert is the largest in the world?
geography.explanation: The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world, covering an area of about 9,200,000 km² in northern Africa.

geography.text: Which mountain range runs through Italy from north to south?
geography.explanation: The Apennines run through Italy from north to south, forming the backbone of the Italian peninsula.

geography.text: Which country has the most borders with other countries?
geography.explanation: China has the most borders with other countries, bordering 14 different nations.

geography.text: Which island is the largest in the Mediterranean?
geography.explanation: Sicily is the largest island in the Mediterranean, with an area of about 25,700 km².

geography.text: Which country has the largest land area in the world?
geography.explanation: Russia is the largest country in the world, with an area of about 17.1 million km².

geography.text: Which city is known as 'The Eternal City'?
geography.explanation: Rome is known as 'The Eternal City' for its long history and its fundamental role in Western civilization.

geography.text: Which country has the most time zones?
geography.explanation: France has the most time zones (12) due to its overseas territories and departments around the world.

geography.text: What is the deepest point in the Earth's oceans?
geography.explanation: The Mariana Trench is the deepest point in the Earth's oceans, reaching a depth of about 11,000 meters.

geography.text: Which country has the most natural lakes?
geography.explanation: Canada has the most natural lakes in the world, with over 2 million lakes covering about 7.6% of the country's land area.

geography.text: What is the highest waterfall in the world?
geography.explanation: Angel Falls in Venezuela is the highest waterfall in the world, with a height of 979 meters.

geography.text: Which country has the most active volcanoes?
geography.explanation: Indonesia has the most active volcanoes in the world, with over 130 active volcanoes.

geography.text: What is the largest coral reef system in the world?
geography.explanation: The Great Barrier Reef is the largest coral reef system in the world, stretching for over 2,300 kilometers along the coast of Australia.

geography.text: Which country has the most islands?
geography.explanation: Sweden has the most islands in the world, with over 267,570 islands.

geography.text: What is the largest salt flat in the world?
geography.explanation: Salar de Uyuni in Bolivia is the largest salt flat in the world, covering over 10,000 square kilometers.

geography.text: Which country has the most UNESCO World Heritage Sites?
geography.explanation: Italy has the most UNESCO World Heritage Sites, with 58 sites as of 2023.

history.text: In which year did World War II end?
history.explanation: World War II ended in 1945 with the surrender of Germany in May and Japan in September.

history.text: In which year did the Berlin Wall fall?
history.explanation: The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, marking the end of the division of Germany.

history.text: Who was the first president of the United States of America?
history.explanation: George Washington was the first president of the United States of America, in office from 1789 to 1797.

history.text: In which year was America discovered by Christopher Columbus?
history.explanation: Christopher Columbus discovered America on October 12, 1492, landing on the island of San Salvador in the Bahamas.

history.text: Which Roman emperor set fire to Rome in 64 AD?
history.explanation: According to tradition, Emperor Nero set fire to Rome in 64 AD, although this accusation has been questioned by modern historians.

history.text: In which year did the French Revolution begin?
history.explanation: The French Revolution began on July 14, 1789, with the storming of the Bastille.

history.text: In which year was John F. Kennedy assassinated?
history.explanation: John F. Kennedy was assassinated on November 22, 1963, in Dallas, Texas.

history.text: Which dynasty ruled China from 1368 to 1644?
history.explanation: The Ming dynasty ruled China from 1368 to 1644, a period of stability and cultural prosperity.

history.text: In which year did the Western Roman Empire fall?
history.explanation: The Western Roman Empire fell in 476 AD when the last emperor, Romulus Augustus, was deposed by Odoacer.

history.text: Which ancient civilization built the city of Machu Picchu?
history.explanation: The Incas built Machu Picchu in the 15th century, high in the Andes Mountains of Peru.

history.text: In which year did the first successful powered flight take place?
history.explanation: The Wright brothers made the first successful powered flight at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, in 1903.

history.text: Which ancient wonder of the world was located in Alexandria?
history.explanation: The Lighthouse of Alexandria was one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, built in the 3rd century BC.

history.text: In which year did the first successful moon landing take place?
history.explanation: The first successful moon landing took place in 1969, when Apollo 11 landed on the lunar surface.

history.text: Which ancient civilization built the city of Petra?
history.explanation: The Nabataeans built the city of Petra in what is now Jordan, carving its famous structures into the rock face.

history.text: Which ancient civilization built the city of Tikal?
history.explanation: The Mayans built the city of Tikal in what is now Guatemala, with its famous pyramids and temples.

history.text: Which ancient civilization built the city of Palmyra?
history.explanation: The Romans built the city of Palmyra in what is now Syria, creating a unique blend of Roman and local architectural styles.
